channel.title: Sector 29 - NotMiles [Album] :spotify:
channel.description:
Before I post the album, here is the epic finale to Sector 29: [<big>**Vault**</big>](https://soundcloud.com/not_miles/vault) (I've been dreaming of an Auxy-Figure crossover for a while and now it's _R E A L_)
![TrueSector29CoverArt|500x500](upload://hreSHzfZnOrDBmZZ6C10SrTKPTW.jpg)
After nearly two months of work, I have finished my sci-fi video game album [<big>**Sector 29**</big>](https://soundcloud.com/not_miles/sets/sector-29) Enjoy!
(Oh, and if you have any feedback for me, feel free to share)

item.title: Sector 29 - NotMiles [Album] :spotify:
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
NotMiles:

reconstructed melodies

Not sure what you mean here.
If you’re not using the melodies as they appear in the source composition, then you won’t need to get a cover license.

If you’ve created something that ‘sounds like the melody from that game’, then the work could be regarded as being ‘heavily inspired’, maybe even ‘derivative’, but probably not technically an infringement.

 

The problem is that (imo) that my style varies a bit to much to keep it consistent on either account.

I have the same issue.
One solution is that you don’t necessarily ‘release’ everything you create. At least, not on Spotify, iTunes, etc…

Keep those ‘proper’ channels focused, using one or two distinct sounds.

I certainly won’t be releasing certain tracks that I had* up on SC.
(* I recently removed half of my SC tracks, removing anything that definitely didn’t fit with the Heathen AKA sound. I’ll be culling more soon as I tighten that account up.)

For instance, I’ve decided that I’ll focus my formal output on two, possibly three, distinct styles – though that ‘3rd’ stuff might be remade slightly and brought under the Heathen AKA banner.

An example of something that doesn’t readily fit would be my ‘Sketch 23’ piece; a brassy, ‘classical’ piece with a mellotron ending. As it stands, it doesn’t fit with Heathen AKA, but by remaking it with a more gritty, synthetic sound, it might make an interesting addition to the Heathen AKA body of work. (And I’d still enjoy the piece in the new form.)

Of course, we need to ask ourselves, is everything we create worthy of a proper release?

We’re on Spotify presumably because we want to take our music more seriously. Part of that is being more critical about the quality of the stuff we’re producing – and/or making sure that everything we do finish really is of the kind of quality that’s going to build an audience.

 
It’s important to understand that ‘Why do I create music?’ and ‘Why do I release music on Spotify, etc…?’ are two different questions.

If you create music for enjoyment, then anything goes.
But, if you’re releasing on Spotify, etc… to make it more serious, then some practical ‘rules’ are going to apply; rules that impact how best to build an audience – and establish yourself as a serious music maker.

The answers to both questions only need to align if you’re set on releasing everything you make on Spotify, …

Read full topic

item.title: Sector 29 - NotMiles [Album] :spotify:
item.dc:creator: NotMiles
item.description:
akabillposters:

The chances of that increase if you have a clearer sound that the audience can relate to.

That makes a lot of sense. That way listeners know what they’re getting into each time. The problem is that (imo) that my style varies a bit to much to keep it consistent on either account. I don’t exactly go into making a song knowing what style it will end up as.

akabillposters:

Don’t bail out on your track idea for the sake of $12.

The song uses reconstructed melodies from four different songs, so that would be $48 (Unless it works differently for songs with multiple covers in it). I don’t think I’m at the stage where I can justify spending $48 on a single song. I definitely don’t get enough streams from Spotify to offset that cost. Don’t get me wrong, I absolutely believe in this song, but my pockets aren’t deep enough to drop that kind of cash every year for one song.

Read full topic

item.title: Sector 29 - NotMiles [Album] :spotify:
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
NotMiles:

Would the royalties be taken from just the one song or the all the songs in the album?

Only the songs which use other people’s compositions. So, if that’s the only track on your release that does that, then you’d only need to register that one track as a ‘cover’ – and you’d only pay the amount required for clearing one track.

Read full topic

item.title: Sector 29 - NotMiles [Album] :spotify:
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
NotMiles:

Simpler for me, tbh. It’s already time consuming enough to run the current account. I’m pretty busy (contrary to what it may seem from all the time I spend on Disco), so having two accounts to consistently create content for may be a bit too much.

It’s not really a case of double the work. It’s just a case of pushing each track you create out through the right artist account.

 

I’m hoping to get a larger fan base outside of the Auxy community.

The chances of that increase if you have a clearer sound that the audience can relate to.

You don’t have to be super-niche, but for example, my Heathen AKA stuff would likely appeal to a different audience as my vocal synth-pop stuff. I’ll be releasing that under a different name.

It comes back to a similar discussion on Disco a while back, when I asked about people’s criteria for reposts. Many didn’t repost because they were trying to build an audience around a more focussed sound – and reposting potentially meant recommending tracks from very different genres to their own, which might deter some of their genre-specific audience.

 

Looks like the version that’s going to stores will have to exclude the melodies. Thanks for the help.

If you believe in the track, as it is, then look into the costs first. You might consider it worth doing. You can always remove/replace it after a year, if you don’t feel it’s worth it.

Don’t bail out on your track idea for the sake of $12. (If you do that, then maybe you don’t have a reasonably strong belief in the track to begin with, in which, why release it on SC?)

Read full topic

item.title: Sector 29 - NotMiles [Album] :spotify:
item.dc:creator: NotMiles
item.description:
Looks like the version that’s going to stores will have to exclude the melodies. Thanks for the help.
Oh wait, I just found out about this Songfile.com thing where I can get the licenses by paying royalties to the original artist. Would the royalties be taken from just the one song or the all the songs in the album?

Can’t find any of the songs on there. Oh well.

Read full topic

item.title: Sector 29 - NotMiles [Album] :spotify:
item.dc:creator: NotMiles
item.description:
akabillposters:

Simple for whom?

Simpler for me, tbh. It’s already time consuming enough to run the current account. I’m pretty busy (contrary to what it may seem from all the time I spend on Disco), so having two accounts to consistently create content for may be a bit too much.

akabillposters:

What are you hoping to achieve by releasing music (on Spotify, iTunes, etc…)?

I’m hoping to get a larger fan base outside of the Auxy community. As it is now, my only followers who aren’t Auxians are my family, a few friends, and a small handful of people who I met while I used Figure. (tbh, it might be kinda hard, since I don’t have any social media, but oh well) Making a bit of cash is pretty nice too (I’ve made a dollar so far…heh).

Read full topic
